Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Understanding the origins and global threat of white-nose syndrome in Asia
Award.AbstractNarration:
The fungal pathogen associated with the disease white-nose syndrome, Pseudogymnoascus destructans, has caused catastrophic declines in hibernating bat populations across eastern North America. This disease now threatens several species in the United States and Canada. The current known distribution of P. destructans includes a large portion of the European continent, but bat populations in Europe have not experienced the same declines as bats in North America. The pathogen is now believed to have long coexistence with European bats, but has only recently been introduced to the United States. No one knows whether P. destructans exists in temperate Asia. Determining the global distribution of P. destructans is important for understanding the origins and global threat of white-nose syndrome. Conditions in China are suitable for pathogen growth and spread, and large numbers of hibernating bats exist in cave habitats in China. In this study P. destructans will be sampled across northeastern China in collaboration with Professor Jiang Feng at Northeast Normal University, a leading expert in bat ecology in China.

Up to 10 caves and mines where bats hibernate during winter across northeastern China for P. destructans will be explored. Samples will be collected from soil and wall substrate, specifically targeting locations where bats roost during winter. Using molecular techniques, samples will be tested at Northeast Normal University for the DNA of P. destructans. Presence of P. destructans in China will show a broad distribution of this pathogen in temperate climates across the Euro-Asian continent. Alternatively, if P. destructans is not present in China, the introduction of this pathogen could pose a major threat to Chinese bat populations. This study will provide critical information on the global risk of human-mediated movement through international caving expeditions of P. destructans to Asia. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a 2014 EAPSI China fellow, I had the opportunity to conduct scientific research in Changchun, Jilin, China at Northeast Normal University (NENU). Under the guidance of my host advisor, Professor Jiang Feng, my research objective was to evaluate whether the fungus, Pseudogymnoascus destructans, the causative agent of white-nose syndrome, was present in bat populations and cave environments in northeastern China. Professor Feng and his team of faculty and graduate students focus on biodiversity conservation, specifically on behavioral ecology and conservation of bats. This collaboration provided the perfect network of researchers to address this question.

            Bats play an important role in ecosystems and are currently at threat from habitat destruction, human persecution due to a perceived threat as disease reservoirs, and the recently emerged fungal disease, white-nose syndrome. White-nose syndrome was introduced to North America in 2006 and has since spread across eastern N. America causing unprecedented mass mortality in bat populations with some species experiencing 90-100% declines. The current known distribution of P. destructans includes a large portion of the European continent, but to date no one has sampled east of Turkey into Asia. Bat populations in Europe have not experienced the same declines as bats in North America, and bats have likely lived with this fungus in Europe for millenia. China is a critical area to conduct this research because the conditions there are conducive for pathogen growth and spread. This region of China also contains large numbers of hibernating bats, and there has recently been an increase in international caving expeditions to this region of the world. These factors put China at significant risk for pathogen introduction if P. destructans is not present.

            During this study I collected over 1000 samples from bats and cave substrate in four Chinese provinces and one municipality. We sampled a total of 10 bats species and 20 cave environments. These samples will allow us to determine the presence and distribution of the fungus, P. destructans. This will also provide the first step in determining whether China maybe at risk of future introductions of this deadly disease.

            The samples are currently being tested for the presence of P. destructans DNA using quantitative PCR. Once we have evaluated whether the fungus is present in these samples, we will isolate and grow fungus from these same samples for further genetic analysis. This study will provide the framework for further investigation into the global distribution of this recently emerged fungal pathogen, allowing for conservation action to reduce the risk of future introductions.

            While conducting my research at NENU, I was able broaden my interests in the international research and conservation community. Furthermore, by taking part in international research collaboration, I was exposed to working with a diverse group of graduate students and professionals, and will be continuing to collaborate with my host Professor Jiang Feng for my dissertation research.
